channel.description:
Draft V3 https://soundcloud.com/thoughtfulnoise/draft-jazzy-dnb/s-netKxiO9rQg
  <hr />
  I'll likely bounce it out to Ableton to replace the placeholder leads (kinda tired of the 'too recognisable' lead options in Auxy).
Drums are kinda placeholder too, but representative of the vibe. (There's a tonal hum in the drums that I'll need to clean out â€” though I'd love to replace with live drums)
So, any thoughts, comments, feedback on what works, what doesn't work, etcâ€¦
That includes any thoughts on what the best fit genre might best. I'm generally coming at it from a electronic + jazz/jazzy perspective, soâ€¦
Thanks

item.description:
The â€˜Auxy finishedâ€™ trackâ€¦

Black Node - Rolling [Jazz Fusion][Thoughtful Noise] Post Your Tracks
Black Node - Rolling [Thoughtful Noise / TN05] [image] [Black_Node_-_Rolling_500x500] Been tweaking this one on and off for while. After wondering if it was too long (at ~5 mins), Iâ€™ve actually extended it to ~7 mins, mainly to add a 64-bar solo. Anyhoo, hereâ€™s the finished(-ish)* track. * The solo was done into Ableton by looping that section of the main track and riffing over the top with a midi keyboard for a few long takes. Then, taking the best bits, compiling them as a solo and addâ€¦

item.description:
Oh, dear. Iâ€™ve been massaging and tweaking this one since this post.
I was just about to lock it down â€” until I realised that what this thing needsâ€¦ is a 64-bar fast solo.

Might be more sane to bounce it and do it in Ableton.

Guess, thatâ€™s my weekend sorted.

 
(So much for â€˜is it too long?â€™ )

item.description:
Youâ€™re welcome! Iâ€™m glad I can help out a little. I totally understand what you mean with the sax notes at higher octaves, as Iâ€™ve experienced that myselfâ€”I forgot about that when typing my previous message. Otherwise, with iammaneâ€™s feedback as well this is going to be a great track!

item.title: WIP Feedback: Uptempo, Jazzy, Liquid(?) DnB(-ish) ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
3:15 seems like a good opportunity to play with the bass some, change up the drums a bit and at that point Iâ€™d really like to hear some rides. Thinking on Jaga Jazzist some, something they do in a lot of their tracks is drop the wall of sound for a bit to explore a different idea entirely. Animal Chin comes to mind, thereâ€™s that break down about 2/3 of the way through where itâ€™s just drums and bass pretty much. 3:15 to like 3:38.

I wouldnâ€™t shorten it though. The length is perfect, thereâ€™s enough variation in there that things stay interesting. And I know you said the ending wasnâ€™t really complete yet, even having it resolve on a lower note thatâ€™s drawn out would do. Or you could do a fade out lol I love fade outs I donâ€™t care what anyone says the vibe it casts would work with a fade

item.title: WIP Feedback: Uptempo, Jazzy, Liquid(?) DnB(-ish) ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
Thanks for that. Some good thoughts in there.

I think Iâ€™ll stick with the length after all. (Not sure what I was thinking when I mentioned trimming out 8 bars. Itâ€™s effectively built on 16-bar passages, so trimming 8 from any 1 section would the feel out.)

Good to know it works for an interested audience.

Youâ€™re right about the sax coming in kinda unexpectedly during the intro build. It could probably work like that, but later. I think itâ€™s good, but it might work better on a breakdown later in the track, once thereâ€™s some momentum (and the general energy level is higher).

Going to a higher octave means potentially entering octaves where the Auxy sax samples start to sound a bit cheap. I think theyâ€™re based on a limited number of key samples, with higher notes seemingly being lower samples reused at higher keys, rather than a fresh resample. And all the breathiness is lost.

I tried the sax on some of the lead melodies, but again, it meant straying upwards into notes where these sax samples donâ€™t sound so convincing.

Good call on adding swing. It could help take the edge of the quantisation just a little.

 
Thanks for the thoughtful feedback. Really appreciate it.

Read full topic
item.source: WIP Feedback: Uptempo, Jazzy, Liquid(?) DnB(-ish) ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸

item.title: WIP Feedback: Uptempo, Jazzy, Liquid(?) DnB(-ish) ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸
item.dc:creator: sn.ow.y
item.description:
I think itâ€™s a pretty good length, and it does keep my attention from pretty much the beginning to the end. Thereâ€™s a lot of variety in the drums and instruments that I enjoy, so I was listening intently all the way through. I enjoy jazz quite a lot, so I was naturally interested in it, but I can imagine someone who isnâ€™t as into jazz clicking off after about a minute. Not a bad thing, just worth a mention to keep my feedback in check.

If you really wanted to make it shorter, I think you could trim about 8 bars off at around 3:00, and another 8 at around 4:30.

About the sax: I think it fits decently, but I feel like it could be softer or at least one octave higher. When it first comes in at around 1:12, I felt like it was too sudden and way to loud in the mix just because it has a lot of low end, but the bass isnâ€™t very in-your-face, and most of the piano/keys donâ€™t have a ton of low end. I think if you made it just a little softer, I think it would sit more nicely in the mix.

To make it feel organic and like a group of people actually played it, I would recommend adding a tiny bit of swing (just increase it by 2-3 at most). The only other thing that I can think of to make it feel like that is to make some of the notes soft, especially for the saxophone. With saxophones, I personally imagine someone actually playing the melody on a sax, and thinking of where the â€œintonationsâ€ (I donâ€™t know the word for itâ€“maybe â€œstressâ€?) would be, and making some of the notes in between those intonations softer.

item.title: WIP Feedback: Uptempo, Jazzy, Liquid(?) DnB(-ish) ğŸ¤·â€â™€ï¸
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
Thanks, @sn.ow.y. I appreciate it.

Do you think itâ€™s a good length? Does it keep your interest from start to finish â€” or does it start to dip anywhere? (Iâ€™m thinking it might benefit from trimming 8-16 bars, after the second breakdown.)

Iâ€™m thinking of having the sax play a bigger role, to give the overall sound palette a bit more interest. (Itâ€™s a tricky one, as the Auxy saxophones can sound good in specific situations, but can quickly stray into sounding like bad midi instruments if not careful.)

Iâ€™ll likely swap out the Auxy Vintage Keys in Ableton for a better Rhodes VST, like , but thatâ€™s mainly because Iâ€™ve absolutely rinsed Vintage Keys â€” in pretty much everything I make.

â€¦plus it wouldnâ€™t hurt to add a little more velocity and volume variation, to make it feel a bit more performed, rather than sequenced.

Iâ€™d like the whole thing to sound less sequenced. Iâ€™d like to loosen things up. Iâ€™m imagining a small (or not-so-small), contemporary jazz unit recording this in the studio.

Think of bands like Jaga Jazzist or Snarky Puppy.
(How might it sound if they performed this? Thatâ€™s close to where Iâ€™d like this to end up.)

Read full topic
